.1	This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the “City”) to prospective Suppliers to submit Bids for Equity and Training Services as further described in Part 3 (Requirements for Deliverables):  The selected Supplier will be required to enter into an agreement with the City for the provision of the Deliverables. The final agreement shall be substantially in the form found in Part 2 (FORM OF AGREEMENT). The number of awarded Suppliers will depend on how many bids are successful after the evaluation. This RFP is divided into two (2) categories, with some categories further broken down into specific topics. Each topic within a category will be awarded separately to up to (3) successful suppliers. Suppliers may submit a Bid on any and all categories or specific topic depending on their expertise and capacity. Suppliers must clearly state which topic(s) they are applying to in their bid submission and how the requirements outlined in Section 3 are met in their bid for each of the topics they are submitting the bidding on. Suppliers may also submit separate bids for each of the topics should they wish to.  The term of the agreement for categories or topic services is to be for a period of one year with an option in favour of the City to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional term of up to four (4) additional one (1) year terms under the terms and conditions of this Agreement. .4	Category Breakdown and Services:                     Category A – Design, Development and Delivery Services.  Category A will be awarded to up to three (3) Suppliers for each topic area, for a total of up to 36 Suppliers. Detailed descriptions of the following topic areas are found under Part 3 of this RFP:  1. Equity, Diversity and Inclusion 2. Accessibility and Disability Inclusion 3. Anti-racism (awards for each topic below will be made to up to three separate Suppliers) 	3.1. General 	3.2. Anti-Indigenous racism 	3.3. Anti-Black racism 	3.4. Antisemitism 	3.5. Islamophobia 	3.6. Anti-Asian racism 4. Human Rights / Workplace Discrimination and Harassment 5. Truth and Reconciliation 6. 2SLGBTQ+ Education 7. Gender Equity and Inclusion Each Supplier is permitted to bid on any category or topic based on their expertise and capability. When the Supplier submits their bids, they may consolidate the categories or topic areas into one proposal but must indicate which categories (i.e., Category A or B or both) or topic areas they are submitting for and showcase their qualifications and experience. If the supplier provides a list of course offerings, please state which topic area the course aligns with or falls under. Category B – Off-the-shelf Digital Course Category B services will be awarded to up to three (3) Suppliers. Detailed descriptions of the category B services are found under Part 3 of this RFP.
Wards: Ward 1 Etobicoke North,Ward 2 Etobicoke Centre,Ward 3 Etobicoke-Lakeshore,Ward 4 Parkdale-High Park,Ward 5 York South-Weston,Ward 6 York Centre,Ward 7 Humber River-Black Creek,Ward 8 Eglinton-Lawrence,Ward 9 Davenport,Ward 10 Spadina-Fort York,Ward 11 University-Rosedale,Ward 12 Toronto-St. Paul’s,Ward 13 Toronto Centre,Ward 14 Toronto-Danforth,Ward 15 Don Valley West,Ward 16 Don Valley East,Ward 17 Don Valley North,Ward 18 Willowdale,Ward 19 Beaches-East York,Ward 20 Scarborough Southwest,Ward 21 Scarborough Centre,Ward 22 Scarborough-Agincourt,Ward 23 Scarborough North,Ward 24 Scarborough-Guildwood,Ward 25 Scarborough-Rouge Park

Solicitation Document Description: Architectural Services for Childrens Services Division
Architectural Services for Childrens Services Division

Quotations are invited for the supply and delivery of eight (8) latest model compact regular cab pickup trucks, 2WD, complete with all steel long body and hinged tailgate in various configurations, for the City of Toronto Fleet Services Division, all in accordance with the attached modified Specification No. 077F-61FL, the complete additional requirements for Parks, Forestry & Recreation Division and Municipal Licensing & Standards Division, the provisions contained in this Request for Quotation (RFQ) and the City of Torontos Procurement Policies, the attached Price Schedules and the City of Toronto Fair Wage Policy and Labour Trades Contractual Obligations in the Construction Industry.
Provision of construction services for Replacement of Emergency / Standby Diesel Engine Generators and ATS at five (5) Toronto Water facilities.

Quotations are invited for the supply and delivery of all labour, materials and equipment necessary to perform annual inspections, provide certification and  repairs for  lifting devices owned and operated by Toronto Fleet Services, Toronto Fire Services and Toronto Emergency Medical Services, all in compliance with the Standard for Maintenance and Inspection of overhead Cranes, Gantry Cranes, Monorails, Hoists and Trolleys CSA-B167-96,  from the date of award of contract to December 31, 2012 with an option to renew, for an additional four (4) separate one year periods  subject to satisfactory performance review and budget availability all in accordance with the attached Price Schedules, Scope of Work, General Requirements, the City of Toronto?s Purchasing Policies, as noted, the Response Requirements, the City of Toronto Fair Wage Policy and Labour Trades Contractual Obligations in the Construction

This RFSQ is an invitation by the City to qualify a minimum of three (3) and a maximum of ten (10) General Contractors for future eligibility for the purpose of establishing a Roster to carry out minor additions, rehabilitation and building repairs to various Parks, Forestry and Recreation facilities.   Description of Deliverables Successful Respondents making up the roster will undertake the construction and delivery of new or improvement work assignments of various scales and complexity, as work assignments arise, up to a maximum contract value per work assignment of $500,000.00, excluding taxes.   Successful Respondents making up the Roster shall be required to provide a response to a Request for Quotations (RFQ) per work assignment, per scope of work and contract documents provided in the work assignment RFQ. The lowest bidder, who meets the mandatory requirements will be awarded the work assignment.  Tasks and deliverables may vary per work assignment, but are generally within the scope of work described

This RFSQ is an invitation by the City to qualify a minimum of three (3) and a maximum of ten (10) General Contractors for future eligibility for the purpose of establishing a Roster to carry out minor additions, rehabilitation and building repairs to various Parks, Forestry and Recreation facilities. Successful Supplier: GHD LIMITED MARK W JOLLEY-N AMERICA CONTROLLER
Solicitation Document Description: optionsThe City of Toronto (“the City”) has made a commitment to combating climate change. In 2019, Toronto City Council declared a climate emergency, and in 2021, it updated the City’s TransformTO Climate Action Strategy to include the goal of reaching net zero GHG emissions by 2040, one of the most ambitious targets in North America.  •	The purpose of this project is to develop a long-term, comprehensive GHG Mitigation Strategy for TW, tailored to TW’s needs and circumstances, with a focus on the next 15 years (i.e., to 2040) but with consideration for the longer-term as well. The Strategy will meet the following high-level objectives: o	Address Council-mandated GHG reduction targets as specified in the City’s TransformTO Net Zero policy of net zero by 2040 (noting that the City’s corporate goals are not necessarily appropriate for TW, and the scope of this project includes setting appropriate goals for TW). o	Coordinate and prioritize TW’s GHG mitigation work. o	Identify financial opportunities and avoid financial risks.  o	Showcase TW’s climate mitigation leadership.  •	The scope of work includes all engineering services related to the development of the GHG Mitigation Strategy and all deliverables in this RFP.  •	Broadly the scope includes the following items: o	Define mission, vision, and guiding principles for TW GHG Mitigation Strategy.  o	Review background information, studies, regulations, and policies related to GHG mitigation. o	Develop the economic framework that will be used to support decision-making for GHG emission reductions.  o	Identify and evaluate potential GHG reduction technologies and strategies and perform a screening analysis for proposed GHG reduction projects.  o	Develop decision-support tools to help Toronto Water to consider GHG emissions in decision-making and tracking.  o	Establish GHG reduction targets aligned with the City’s TransformTO Net Zero policy using the identified projects that can be undertaken to achieve GHG reduction targets. o	Create communications materials to communicate various aspects of the TW GHG Mitigation Strategy to Toronto Water staff and other stakeholders. o	Summarize past and ongoing efforts relating to Scope 3 emissions and recommend a path forward for considering Scope 3. o	Prepare a final GHG Mitigation Strategy Report that integrates findings from all phases of the project, including recommendations for implementation, monitoring, and continuous improvement.

The goal for this assignment is for the Successful Supplier to provide engineering professional services to assist the City of Toronto in the preliminary design phase of Assignment 45-48 in the Basement Flooding Protection Program (BFPP). This assignment was identified as part of BFPP Class EA Study Area 45 and BFPP Class EA Study Area 4 Update and is located in Ward 5 (York South - Weston).  Area 45 BF EA was completed in 2021 and a bundle of solutions were identified after study completion and have been named Assignment 45-48. The Assignment includes but is not limited to combined sewer separation, new storm sewers, storm sewer replacement, sanitary sewer replacement, stormwater storage, new outfall, and inlet control devices.

•	  Toronto Water (TW) through this Request for Proposal (RFP) is soliciting proposals from qualified Suppliers to provide professional services to study and provide platform(s) recommendations with their pros and cons where TW can access or retrieve geo-spatial documents among other document/file formats such as text, data, audio, 3D images, pdf, etc. •	The selected Supplier will be expected to research, and make recommendations for the necessary services, software, and/or hardware that meet the needs of TW’s central platform for accessing geo-spatial and other documents in their respective repositories. •	In addition, the recommended platform(s) will be scalable, and seamlessly integrate or interface with existing or future document management systems within TW and the City of Toronto.  •	TW currently has several electronic document management systems (EDMSs) in silos that are neither integrated nor interfaced with one another. The objective of this project is to engage a Supplier, a company or consultant, to study and provide recommendations to TW to implement a centralized access or retrieval platform using any of the existing EDMS platforms or a net new platform as the case may be. The selected consultant will be required to conduct a thorough study and assessment of the current siloed TW and/or City of Toronto document management systems; the DMS of other jurisdictions (including outside Canada); and other DMSs available in the market. The study will identify the capabilities of the platform, or limitations that may impact their ability to serve as an effective centralized enterprise platform for TW. •	The recommended platform is expected to have the capabilities to access spatially enabled information and retrieve geospatial details. •	This Study is Phase 1, and a Phase 2 is planned as the Implementation Phase. •	The Supplier is advised that providing consulting services for Phase 1 is not a guarantee they will also be selected to provide their consulting services for Phase 2. Also, it is expected that any Phase 1 work and reporting by the Supplier will be free of bias that would favour them to provide Phase 2.

The Capital Project Design and Delivery Section (CPDD) of the Parks & Recreation Division (P&R) provides capital project design and delivery services for PFR’s extensive and diverse assets. Due to the large volume of unanticipated/emergency work required, and in an effort to be able to service its clients in a reasonable and timely manner, the City reserves the right to enter into a Contract with two (2) successful General Contractors who have the highest evaluation scores (Part4 -Form B Technical Proposal and Qualifications) meeting mandatory requirements to perform the tasks associated with this Request for Proposal (RFP). Should the General Contractor have satellite locations available, this information must be provided by the General Contractor (Part 4 - Form C) for Award consideration. The work is spread out in two geographical areas, i.e. North & East Districts, and South (including Toronto Islands) & West Districts and one contractor will be hired for each geographical after evaluation by the City. Suppliers are required to indicate their preference of geographical area in their submission. The proponent with the highest score will be assigned their preferred geographical area while the second highest will be assigned the other geographical area. The City will make every effort to ensure an even distribution of work between the two successful Contractors. The Contractor must remain flexible to work at any geographical area. The City reserves the right to allocate any contract to one of the successful contractors, irrespective of the geographical area.  The term of the Contract is to be for a period of (3) three years from the date of award, with an option to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional two, one (1) year terms. The option to renew is at the discretion of the City and will be subject to budget availability and General Contractor's performance.

Solicitation Document Description: Construction of the Bluffer’s Park East Washroom Improvements and Exterior Works  The City is improving the east washroom and maintenance building in Bluffer’s Park. This project includes upgrades to the existing washroom and maintenance building and a new outdoor plaza, with amenities and landscaping.  The existing building will be demolished and replaced with a new building.  Due to the age of the existing building designated substances will be required to be mitigated before demolition begins.  Refer to Designated Substance Survey which can be found in the Reference Section of Part 3 – Specifications and Drawings of the sourcing event in Ariba, forming part of the Contract Document.  Bluffer’s Park East Washroom will be improved with the following:  Phase 1 New all-season gender-inclusive and accessible washrooms •	Administrative and support spaces for maintenance and operation staff including a garage •	New mechanical/electrical/lighting systems that are net-zero carbon •	Outdoor showers •	Outdoor plaza with seating and bike parking  Phase 2 •	Accessible pathways within the landscape including to the beach •	Play spaces •	Plantings including shade trees, pollinator, and native species
Wards: Ward 20 Scarborough Southwest

Solicitation Document Description: This nRFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the "City") to prospective vendors to submit Bids for the provision of Operations and Maintenance Services at the Dufferin Organic Processing Facility (DOPF) located at 75 Vanley Crescent, Toronto, ON M3J 2B7. This facility processes 55,000 metric tones of Organic Material per Operating Year. The City expects to award one (1) contract to one (1) Supplier entity. The responsibilities of the City and the Supplier within the Scope of Work are described in Part -3 Requirements for Deliverables section 1.2 and 1.3 of the nRFP.  Note: Suppliers shall download, complete and sign to submit a copy of Appendix E - Non-Disclosure Agreement Schedule to the Procurement Contact listed in Part 1 - RFP Process, Section- 1.5 Procurement Contact via Ariba to receive access to Appendix C - DOPF Operations and Maintenance Manual.

1.1	GENERAL SCOPE OF WORK .1	The purpose of this RFP is to select a qualified prime Consultant and sub-Consultant team that includes Architectural, Structural, Mechanical, Electrical, Pool, Cost and other specialized professionals, e.g. Sustainability Consultant, to provide full architectural and engineering design and contract administration services to carry out the State of Good Repair Rehabilitation project at the Jimmie Simpson Recreation Centre located at 870 Queen St E, Toronto, ON M4M 3G9, as required by the Capital Projects Unit of Parks, Forestry and Recreation (PF&R) Division of the City of Toronto on behalf of the Parks unit of Parks, Forestry and Recreation.  The Specific Scope of Work to include but not limited to:  ARCHITECTURAL State of good repair Outdoor Artificial Ice Rink (AIR) .1	AIR rebuild .2	AIR change rooms upgrades .3	AIR office upgrades .4 	Code upgrades for AIR equipment room. .5	AIR roof (schematic design and design development only)  Net Zero .1	Building condition assessment, Net Zero Study, modelling  EXTERIOR State of good repair .1	metal cladding .2	redesign entrance to building, accessibility and better visibility .3	windows review incl. add windows for youth space, multipurpose rooms, and staff offices  POOL state of good repair .1	pool tank and deck modification .2	Review and upgrade pool filtration flows, code requirements .3	leisure feature for pool,  .4	upgrades to gallery space .5	Pool ramp, pool access  INTERIOR State of good repair .1	concrete floor refinishes .2	elevator .3	Upgrade washrooms on lower level, main and 2nd floor, accessibility .4	family change room for pool .5	CRP (community recreation programmer) office modification on main floor .6	gym flooring & walls refinish with durable materials .7	storage for gym equipment .8	main stairwell redesign, modification to create usable programming space  MECHANCIAL AND ELECTRICAL .1	Dehumidification for pool .2	Reznor unit for drop ceiling .3	BMS (building management system) upgrades/replacement .4	Boiler and heat exchange for pool (increase capacity and provide redundancy) .5	Review cooling options for gym and basement rooms .6	Review F/A (Fire Alarm) and life safety, upgrade as necessary .7	Electrical upgrades to facilitate current and future work for TGS and NZ (Toronto Green Standard, Net Zero), additional cooling .8	All new mechanical equipment must contribute to net zero emissions.

Work of this Contract comprises of interior and exterior site improvements at Disco Transfer Station, located at 120 Disco Road, Toronto, ON M9W 1M4, Canada.  Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning replacement work includes the following activities:  Exterior - Roof  • Disconnection and removal of five existing roof exhaust fans and one multi-zone air handling unit.  • Installation of five new roof exhaust fans and one new multi-zone air handling unit.  • Removal of existing roof curbs and installation of new roof curbs to suit new equipment.  • Disconnection of existing power and replacement with new power to the five rooftop exhaust fans and one multi-zone air handling unit.  Interior - Administration Building  • Verify and make note of all existing controls and sequence of operations of the existing HVAC system in order to apply the same sequence of operations to the new air handling unit, S-7. Provide control wiring to interlock existing motorized dampers and fans to the new multi-zone air handling unit, S-7.  • Removal of eight multi-zone air handling unit thermostats and replace with eight new thermostats for new multi-zone air handling unit, S-7.  • Decommission existing boiler, drain glycol system and remove existing heating water supply and return to existing multi-zone air handling unit.  • Removal of existing multi-zone panel located in third floor office and replace with new multi-zone panel.

The purpose of this RFP is to select a Qualified Security Assessor (QSA) to conduct a Payment Card Industry compliance assessment and validate the City adherence to PCI DSS with valid version. RFP-22ECS-LU-02FP  The scope to be delivered under this RFP will consist of a number of storm drainage improvement Projects, which may include, but not be limited to: sanitary sewer upgrades, combined sewer upgrades, storm sewer upgrades, new storm or sanitary system infrastructure, trunk sewer upgrades, separation of CSO system through installation of new storm sewer systems, watercourse adjustment and restoration, in-line and off-line storage and box culverts, catch basin inlet controls, outfall/outlet control structures, stormwater management facilities (i.e. ponds, wetlands, tanks and tunnels) and other associated municipal infrastructure work and appurtenances. The works may also include road resurfacing and/or reconstruction, road and boulevard component restoration and/or reconstruction, road safety improvements, construction of sidewalk and other public realm improvements, watermain replacement, lateral services replacements (sewers and water), and utilities relocation works.  The approximate timeline for this Program is expected to be eight (8) years plus post construction services during the two year warranty period for each construction contract, for a total of ten (10) years.  The Basement Flooding Protection Program (BFPP) Assignments to be delivered under this RFP have been divided into two Bundles of work, and each Bundle will be awarded to one Consultant, for a total of two Consultants.  The scope of work in this RFP for Phase 5 of the Basement Flooding Protection Program (BF5) includes the main activities listed below:  • Program and project management services.  • EA studies review.  • Data collection.  • Hydraulic modelling.  • Preliminary design engineering services.  • Geotechnical/hydrogeological investigations.  • Detailed design engineering services.  • Excess soil management.  • Tender preparation and procurement support.  • Quality assurance materials testing during construction.  • Construction contract administration, including site inspection and field ambassadors.  • Post-construction services.  The BF5 Assignment Bundles included in the RFP, for which EA reports have already been completed, are as follows:  • Bundle 1: EA assignments moving forward for Area 40 (40-02, 40-03, 40-06, 40-07, 40-12, 40-13, and 40-14). The RFP will have a total capital delivery capacity of up to $115M, excluding HST, for Bundle 1 and its related add-on scope.  • Bundle 2: EA assignments moving forward for Areas 34, 36, 38, and 41 (34-06A/34-07A, 34-08, 34-12, 34-13, 36-12, 36-13, 38-24, and 41-01). The RFP will have a total capital delivery capacity of up to $100M, excluding HST, for Bundle 2 and its related add-on scope.

This contract includes Work at three (3) Sewage Pumping Stations  (SPS) in the City of Toronto, namely, Cumber SPS, Mimico SPS,  and New Toronto SPS. There are following Works, in general, to be  performed at these SPS: • Cumber SPS:  o Approximately 443 m of Twin 600 mm diameter  Forcemains installation on Lawrence Avenue East  from the SPS to the proposed Discharge  Maintenance Hole including new Valve Chamber  installation and replacement of the existing Valve  Chamber, and o Processing, Structural, Electrical, Mechanical, and  Instrumentation Work inside the Pumping Station. • Mimico SPS:  Approximately 20 m of Twin 600 mm diameter  Forcemains installation including replacement of the  existing Valve Chamber,  o New Valve Chamber installations on the existing 600  mm diameter Forcemains at Albert Avenue and Cavell  Avenue intersection, and o Processing, Structural, Electrical, Mechanical, and  Instrumentation Work inside the Pumping Station. New Toronto SPS:  o Approximately 22 m of Twin 500 mm diameter  Forcemains installation including replacement of  existing valves, o New Valve Chamber installation on the existing 500  mm diameter Forcemain at Morrison Street and  Eleventh Street, and o Processing, Structural, Electrical, Mechanical, and  Instrumentation Work inside the Pumping Station. Additionally, this contract also includes in general: A pre-survey of  all properties and CCTV inspection of existing sewers and  maintenance holes prior to commencement of the Work, installation  of new and/or removal of existing chambers, replacement of valves,  abandonment and/or removal of the existing pipes, temporary  bypassing of the SPS during the Work, testing and commissioning  of the installed forcemains, and Permanent Restoration.  Additionally, this contract also includes in general: A pre-survey of  all properties and CCTV inspection of existing sewers and  maintenance holes prior to commencement of the Work, installation  of new and/or removal of existing chambers, replacement of valves,  abandonment and/or removal of the existing pipes, temporary  bypassing of the SPS during the Work, testing and commissioning  of the installed forcemains, and Permanent Restoration.

Successful Supplier: RV ANDERSON ASSOCIATES LTD ATTN: INAYAT ALI
Solicitation Document Description: •	The City of Toronto requires professional engineering services to analyze the trunk sewer systems servicing the Bermondsey and Massey Creek sewersheds to identify capacity constraints based on current and future growth scenarios, and to provide solution options, an assessment of those options and a preferred recommended solution.   •	The Golden Mile Secondary Plan Area (“the Golden Mile”) is located in Scarborough and is one of the many significant redevelopment areas within the City of Toronto, encompassing approximately 119 hectares along Eglinton Avenue East between Victoria Park Avenue and Birchmount Road. Current land use in the area consists of large-format retail buildings and surface parking with low-rise commercial and industrial buildings to the north and south of Eglinton Avenue East.   •	The Eglinton Crosstown Light Rail Transit (ECLRT) will pass through the Golden Mile and has five surface transit platforms constructed that will help transition the area into a mixed-use, transit-oriented community. A number of development applications have been submitted within the Golden Mile and are currently under review. The latest population proposed for the Golden Mile includes is approximately 67,000 new residents and 9,000 new jobs, which exceeds the City’s population forecasts.   •	Current sanitary drainage areas show that the Golden Mile is currently serviced by two trunk sewers: the Bermondsey Sanitary Trunk Sewer to the west and the Massey Creek Sanitary and Relief Trunk Sewers to the east, with a drainage divide generally at Warden Avenue. •	A master servicing report for the redevelopment of the Golden Mile was carried out by a landowners’ group in early 2020 and updated in 2022. Several servicing alternatives were considered and ultimately recommended upgrades on both the developer and City side to accommodate the Golden Mile development area. These previous studies and recommendations have led the City to this current study which will evaluate and confirm capacity in the trunk system considering the City projected 2051 populations and the latest proposed developments within a wider study area.   •	The Supplier will develop an implementation plan and strategy to prioritize and sequence the recommended wastewater system upgrades and improvements to align with projected incremental growth. The City anticipates the solution will benefit both the existing system and future growth.

This Request for Supplier Qualifications ("RFSQ") is an invitation by the  City of Toronto ("the City") to prospective Respondents to prequalify for  future eligibility to provide professional general contracting services for a  total of approximately 350 small capital projects and emergency capital  projects per year for the City of Toronto Project Management Office,  Corporate Real Estate Management Division  Where a Work Assignment having a cost under $70,000 value including  construction contingency and cash allowances where applicable HST  excluded, the Work Assignment shall be assigned in accordance with the  Rotational Process set out in Schedule B1 of Part 4- Form of Agreement. Where a Work Assignment having a cost exceeding $70,000 value  including construction contingency and cash allowances where applicable  HST excluded, all vendors on the roster list will be required to participate  second stage competitive bidding process. The City will issue an RFQ to all  Rosters Vendors on the Roster List in accordance with the RFQ Process  set out in Schedule B2 of Part 4- Form of Agreement. The debt collection agency services have  been segmented into the three (3) following categories:  • "First (1st) Assignment" These accounts have been  in default for up to 2 years from the date of the  Accounts Receivable Report based on the debtor. All of these accounts have been previously  assigned in third party collections. • "Third (3rd) Assignment" These accounts have been  in default for more than 20 years. All of these accounts  have been previously assigned in third party  collections.

Solicitation Document Description: This Request for Quotation (the "RFQ") is an invitation by the City of  Toronto (the "City") to prospective Suppliers to submit bids for  STARS Supports Assessment Tool, to conduct an evaluation of  the City of Toronto's Service Triage, Assessment and Referral  Support ("STARS") Supports Assessment Tool and Rubric. The  STARS Supports Assessment is conducted by homelessness  service providers (e.g. shelters, street outreach) as part of the  process of connecting people to available City-contracted housing  and support opportunities. City staff use the information from the  submitted STARS Supports Assessment to determine if an  appropriate match to available supports can be made, using a  Rubric designed to support this process, as further described in Part  3 and the Contract (the "Deliverables").

.1	SSLTC requires supply, delivery and warranty of healthcare pillows, comforters and bedspreads, as well as other various bedding related products and accessories for resident rooms and beds.  .2	Orders for bedding products will be placed on an as-needed basis throughout the term of the contract. The quantity and frequency of orders may vary across Homes. Orders may not commence immediately upon contract initiation. .3	The procurement and resident care teams considered the following key factors when developing the product specifications outlined in subsequent sections:  •	Resident comfort;  •	Pressure relief; •	Resident safety; •	Durability and quality; •	Infection control and ease of cleaning; •	Fire safety / flame resistance. .4	SSLTC requires pillows of one standard size. .5	SSLTC requires comforters of one standard size (twin size).  .6	SSLTC may also purchase other bedding products, on as-needed basis. Those may include, but are not limited to: comforters in other sizes, bedspreads of various sizes and styles.  .7	Please note that detailed specifications for those additional items SSLT may or may not purchase will not be provided in the Part 3 of this RFQ. Instead, up to 20 percent of the total contract value will be allocated for miscellaneous bedding products. Please refer to Part 5 of this RFQ for more details. .8	Purchases under the miscellaneous category will be made at the discretion of the City, based on availability of suitable products in the catalog of the successful supplier, alignment with quality expectations, and competitive pricing. .9	SSLTC reserves the right not to purchase miscellaneous items if the available options will not meet requirements in terms of quality, specifications or cost. .10	SSLTC is seeking a Supplier who can provide high-quality products that align with these key considerations to support the health and safety of residents.

Request for Proposals for an environmental consulting firm to undertake a comprehensive Noise, Odour, and Air Quality Assessment (NOAQA) for the McCleary Precinct.  The McCleary Precinct study area is located east of downtown Toronto and is bounded by Lake Shore Boulevard to the north, Commissioner Street to the south, the Don Roadway to the west, and Logan Avenue to the east. Historically, land in the study area has been used for a variety of industrial and bulk storage uses, and a municipal waste transfer station. Currently, the surrounding land uses include a mix of commercial, industrial, film studios, open space, and vacant land.  The NOAQA will be conducted to inform the development of the McCleary Precinct Plan, the development of Zoning By-laws and Official Plan Amendments, and other relevant implementation tools. The assessment will focus on the effects of noise, odour, and air quality on the proposed open space network, land use, and three massing and built form scenarios.

Disco Road Organics Processing Facility Tip Floor RehabilitationThe Works includes but is not limited to the following:a. Project startup including mobilization to the Site.b. Development, implementation, and maintenance of a Site-specific Health and Safety Plan, including provision of COR certification.c. Development and maintenance of a construction schedule outlining the dates for construction, for approval by the OWNER.d. Provision and maintenance of temporary facilities and controls.e. Demolition, Transportation and Disposal as per Section 02 41 19.13.f. Removal and assessment of condition of existing drainage sump covers, in conjunction with OWNER and CONTRACT ADMINISTRATOR.g. Cleaning of drainage sumps, assessment for any required repairs or re-lining.h. Repairs of sump cover frames, and sump covers, or new cover fabrication accordance with OWNER and CONTRACT ADMINISTRATOR directive, and replacement of sump covers in repaired frames.i. Removal of existing clean-out covers, and replacement with new clean-out covers.j. Supply and installation of wear indicators.k. Replacement and rehabilitation of the DROPF tip floor with high-performance concrete with or without resin-based materials as top coating. The tip floor rehabilitation scope of works are:1) Base scope: Topping System Replacement with high-performance concrete levelling and drainage sloping layer, with monolithically poured (thickened levelling layer) exposed concrete topping overlay (Full Area).a) This includes full area rehabilitation with the application of high-performance concrete with a full-depth topping thickness.2) Provisional scope: Topping System Replacement with high-performance concrete levelling and drainage sloping layer, with monolithically poured (thickened levelling layer) exposed concrete topping overlay across part of floor area, and resin topping overlay part of floor area.a) This includes full area rehabilitation with high-performance concrete similar to base scope. In addition, includes partial area rehabilitation of areas that are more prone to damage with the application of an exposed resin coating in a select area.3) Provisional scope: Topping System Replacement with high-performance concrete levelling and drainage sloping layer, and resin topping overlay across full floor area.a) This includes full area rehabilitation with high-performance concrete similar to base scope, with resin coating across entire tip floor area.Demobilization and closeout.Refer to Part 3 Tender Spec for more details

The new Multifunction station for Toronto Paramedic Services, will be located at 330 progress avenue, Scarborough, Ontario. The site is bordered by highway 401 to the north, and an existing Toronto Police Services building to the south. The multi-function station will be divided into five main program groups: • Support and command post for the district and will consist of a group of office and meeting rooms  • Paramedic facilities support the daily paramedic shift cycle with locker rooms, a fitness room, and a staff kitchen and lounge • Education facilities will support the training needs of new and current paramedics in state-of -the-art classrooms, labs, and seminar rooms • Logistics facilities will provide for the cleaning and re-stocking of the ambulance fleet. • Vehicle bays will house 40 ambulances and additional support vehicles. Vehicles will depart from the facility on a regularly scheduled basis, little to no emergency dispatching will take place from this facility. Net Zero Carbon and Net Zero Energy are key drivers of the project. The orientation and massing, envelope detailing, window area, structure, mechanical and electrical systems are all designed towards low energy and zero emissions. There will be no natural gas infrastructure on the site - all building systems, including emergency power, will be electrical.

Solicitation Document Description: This contract includes Work at three (3) Sewage Pumping Stations (SPS) including forcemain works in the City of Toronto, namely, Fallingbrook SPS, Greyabbey SPS, and Humber SPS. There are following Works, in general, to be performed at these SPS:  Fallingbrook SPS forcemain: •	Approximately 105m of 150mm diameter High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) sanitary forcemain replacement from the sewage pumping station to the existing Maintenance Hole at Fallingbrook Crescent, and •	Processing, Structural, Electrical, Mechanical, and Instrumentation Work inside the Pumping Station.  Greyabbey SPS forcemain: •	Approximately 310m of twin 150mm diameter High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) sanitary forcemain replacement from 150m south of Fordover drive to 100m west of Fintona avenue.  •	Replacement of the existing discharge Maintenance Hole, and •	Processing, Structural, Electrical, Mechanical, and Instrumentation Work inside the Pumping Station.  Humber SPS forcemain: •	Approximately 223m of twin 150mm diameter High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) sanitary forcemain replacement from the sewage pumping station to the existing Maintenance Hole at Brule Terrace, and •	Replacement of the existing discharge Maintenance Hole.  Additionally, this contract also includes in general: A pre-construction survey of all properties and CCTV inspection of existing sewers and maintenance holes prior to commencement of the Work, installation of new and/or removal of existing chambers, temporary bypassing of the SPS during the Work, testing and commissioning of the installed forcemains, and Permanent Restoration.
Wards: Ward 4 Parkdale-High Park,Ward 20 Scarborough Southwest,Ward 25 Scarborough-Rouge Park

The purpose of this RFP is to select a qualified consultant or consultant team (the “Consultant”) with expertise in professional learning and development, housing, and human rights-based approaches to policy development, to develop and implement a 'Housing as a Human Right' training program for City staff in housing-related City divisions, agencies and corporations. Solicitation Document Description: The City of Toronto is seeking a Design Consultant to provide professional and technical Services for design, preparation of solicitation documents, and contract administration of the new construction of the targeted net zero emissions project George Street Revitalization at 339 George Street, Toronto.   This nRFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the “City”) to prospective qualified Architectural Consultant Teams (Supplier) to submit Bids to provide complete architectural and professional design services with respect to the redevelopment of Seaton House as part of the George Street Revitalization Project (“GSR”). The GSR will be delivered under the CCDC5 Construction Management contract. The GSR will see the reinvention of the northern most block of George Street and transform Seaton House men’s shelter into a world-class facility providing specialized care for vulnerable populations, including a long-term care home, a transitional shelter, an emergency shelter, transitional housing with supports and a community hub serving residents of both the site and the local neighbourhood. The GSR project will be the catalyst for a more safe and vibrant community for all in the heart of the historic Garden district.  Please note that the solicitation dates are placeholders only and are subject to change.
Wards: Ward 13 Toronto Centre

Solicitation Document Description: The Supplier must provide in its Bid, the documents set out in Part 4 – Form C – Other Mandatory Submission Forms, which include the following documents. These documents shall contain the information set out below. Failure to provide the required information listed below shall render the Bid noncompliant.  1.	Concentration of Iron Salts Suppliers must upload a copy of the concentration of any Iron Salts to be supplied to the City of Toronto as outlined in Part 3 – Specifications and Requirements, 1.2.1.  2.	Manufacturer's Literature and Technical specifications of the Iron Salts Suppliers must upload a copy of the manufacture's literature and technical specifications of the Iron Salts to be supplied to the City of Toronto. 3.	Safety Data Sheet (SDS) Suppliers must upload a copy of the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for each item being supplied to the City of Toronto.  4.	Certificate of Analysis of Iron Salts Suppliers must upload a copy of the Certificate of Analysis of Iron Salts proposed for supply, from a third party accredited laboratory performed within past twelve (12) months. The Certificate of Analysis shall provide a summary of parameters stated in Section 3.1.2, for each Iron Salt to be supplied to the City of Toronto (spent &/or manufactured).  5.	Process Used for Manufacturing Iron Salts and Source of Supply Suppliers must upload a copy of the sources of supply for all products indicating the name and address of the mill(s) and/or manufacturer(s). The copy must state the process used to manufacture the Iron Salts for all products supplied to the City of Toronto.

The RFQ is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the “City”) to prospective Suppliers to submit bids for the non-exclusive provision of Processing Services for up to 35,000 tonnes annually of Yard Waste Material with or without Haulage Services, as further described in Part 3 and the Contract (the “Deliverables”). Refer to RFQ Part 2 Agreement and 3 Spec for more details.  It is the City’s intention to award each Option (Option 1) processing of up to 20,000 tonnes and (Option 2) processing of up to 15,000 tonnes of Yard Waste to two (2) separate legal entities with or without Haulage Services based on the Supplier’s meeting specifications and providing the lowest overall costs in each Contract. Compliant Bids will be ranked based on the lowest total submitted pricing per each Contract and shown in Part 5 – Pricing Form. Suppliers may submit a bid for either one or both Options: Option 1 - processing of up to 20,000 tonnes and/or Option 2 -processing of up to 15,000 tonnes of Yard Waste material. If one supplier offers the lowest cost for both Option 1 and Option 2, the City will award this supplier with Option 1 (20,000 tonnes) ONLY and award Option 2 (15,000 tonnes) to the next supplier with the lowest cost meeting specifications for Option 2. ONE SUPPLIER WILL NOT BE AWARDED FOR BOTH OPTIONS

This RFP is an invitation by the City of Toronto (the "City") to prospective suppliers to submit Bids for The Hostile Vehicle Mitigation Guidelines for Right-of-Way Encroachments, which will establish design, placement, and performance standards for HVM measures that are installed by private property owners and encroach on the public right-of-way. The successful vendor will work with relevant City staff to develop these standards, which will align with existing City policies, procedures, and objectives, and define the process through which property owners may seek approval to encroach in the right-of-way for HVM installations. The successful vendor will develop materials to communicate these standards and procedures to private property owners and to inform them about the range of HVM approaches and product types that align with City requirements, as further described in Part 3 (Requirements for Deliverables):

Solicitation Document Description: Watermain CIPP Lining in Etobicoke York District, Wards 03  and 05. The contract includes in general the following work:  • A pre-survey of all properties before the commencement  of lining and service upgrade work to determine the status  of water meters and the size, material, and location of all  water services. • Where existing water services are found to be  substandard, the work shall include the installation of new  copper water services from the existing water main to the  street line. • Rehabilitation of existing watermains of various sizes by  the installation of a CIPP including cleaning, inspection  and testing.  • Replacement of existing valves, hydrants, and fittings.  • Replacement or rehabilitation of hydrant leads and existing  service connections which are 100 mm and larger in  diameter.  • Temporary watermain bypass and services during  installation.  • Permanent Restoration.

Marine Water Taxi Services for Transportation to and from the Island Water Treatment Plant for Toronto Water Division. The duration of the contract will be for a one (1) year period with the option to renew for four (4) separate one-year periods. Service will only be required during April to October.  Trips will be scheduled in two categories: i)	 Monday to Friday (excluding Statutory Holidays), where the service will require up to the following trips: (1)	Each day, four (4) trips incoming will be made from the City-mainland to the Island WTP and five (5) outgoing trips will be made from the Island WTP to the City-mainland. Two (2) of the outgoing five trips will be classified as "return / round trips."  ii)	 Saturday, Sunday, & Statutory Holidays, where the service will require up to the following trips: (1)	Each day, two (2) incoming trips will be made from the mainland to the Island WTP, and two (2) outgoing trips will be made from the Island WTP to the mainland. These trips will be classified as "return / round trips."

This Request for Proposals is an invitation by the City of Toronto to prospective Suppliers to submit bids for the Trunk Watermain (WM) 2025 Joint Optimization Study (JOS). The City and York Region are seeking a Supplier to update the JOS model, incorporating future growth scenarios to better align water infrastructure investments with projected growth. The Supplier will also perform long-term future scenario analyses, using population and employment projections from the Growth Study, as well as extrapolated data, to evaluate potential expansions of the water infrastructure over the next 80-100 years. This analysis will ensure timely upgrades, preventing the overburdening of resources. The study will focus on the trunk water systems of Toronto and York Region, utilizing advanced hydraulic modeling tools.

For Watermain CIPP Lining in Etobicoke York District, Wards 3, 4 and 5. The contract includes in general the following work:  • A pre-survey of all properties before the commencement of lining and service upgrade work to determine the status of water meters and the size, material, and location of all water services. • Where existing water services are found to be substandard, the work shall include the installation of new copper water services from the existing water main to the street line. • Rehabilitation of existing watermains of various sizes by the installation of a CIPP including cleaning, inspection and testing.  • Replacement of existing valves, hydrants, and fittings.  • Replacement or rehabilitation of hydrant leads and existing service connections which are 100 mm and larger in diameter.  • Temporary watermain bypass and services during installation.  • Permanent Restoration.

Any bids from Trade Partner Suppliers, Non-American Suppliers and US Based Suppliers will be deemed non-compliant and rejected. .3	In accordance with the Canada European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), bids will only be accepted from Canadian Suppliers and Trade Partner Suppliers. Bids from USA Based Suppliers will be deemed non-compliant and rejected. .4	The Successful Supplier will be required to either (i) execute a Contract, or (ii) acknowledge the Contract as contained in the City's purchase order for the provision of the Deliverables. Suppliers should review the terms and conditions set out in Part 2 (FORM OF AGREEMENT) to understand the Contract being entered into with the City. It is the City’s intention to enter into a Contract with only one (1) legal entity. The term of the Contract is to be for a period of one (1) year with an option in favour of the City to extend the agreement on the same terms and conditions for an additional term of up to four (4) additional separate one (1) year periods. .5	The City reserves the right, at its sole and absolute discretion, to not award some or all of the Optional Extension Years as part of the award of the contract to the successful Supplier, in the event that the cumulative cost of such Optional Extension Years combined with the cost of the original contract term exceeds the monetary thresholds established by the Canada European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). .6	This RFQ shall be interpreted in accordance with Section 3.14 (Definitions and Interpretation) and the City's Policies and Legislation. .7	Invitation to submit a Bid, including participation in any pre-qualification, request for information or other similar process or exchange of information prior to the RFQ, does not imply that a Supplier is automatically prequalified to meet the requirements of the RFQ or that the factors which were examined during such process or exchange may not be re-examined or re-evaluated by the City during the consideration and selection process for this RFQ. It will still be necessary for the Supplier to demonstrate its qualifications through the RFQ process.

For Blantyre Park Outdoor Pool Improvements 1.	Part A - Mobilization, Demolition, Removals & General Site Clean-Up i.	Mobilization, demobilization, coordination of sub-trades, bonding, site security, temporary fences and tree protection fencing & facilities, utility locates, sediment control, dust control, staging, traffic control, signs and other costs required for compliance with General and Supplementary Requirements and Division 1. ii.	Stripping, removal and disposal of existing topsoil, lawns and sand, as indicated on drawings and in specifications, including haulage and disposal. iii.	Demolition, removal and disposal or relocation as indicated for various items including playground equipment, benches, chain link fencing, concrete pads, asphalt pavement, and any other site furnishing noted on drawings, inclusive of any footings.  2.	Part B - Site Work & Restoration i.	Subsection 1 - Earthworks, Drainage, Finish Surfacing, and Restoration i.	Grading and earthworks, including bulk excavation, rough grading, backfilling and fine grading. ii.	Supply & install new sub-drainage works. iii.	Supply and install new concrete pavement with integral colouring for new splash pad deck and concrete pavement (natural-grey colour) for all other paved areas, incl. pads for new benches, picnic tables and bike racks. iv.
